Farm to Plate—Redesigning America’s Food System

Over the last ten weeks, Cabot Middle School students have been learning about agriculture, food systems, nutrition, and the three pillars of sustainability (social, environmental, and economic). Students researched USDA guidelines and created personalized menus; they learned about photosynthesis, climate, and how to build and maintain healthy soil; they investigated the biochemical reactions in bread-making; they examined fundamental components of the US food system like industrial meat and sugar production....and much more!

As part of this exploration, students designed “expert” projects driven by personal interests. Sample projects include a podcast featuring Snug Valley Farm in East Hardwick, a TED Talk about fast food and obesity, an “explainer video” about ultra-processed foods, an analysis of added sugar in our diet.. and more! Ultimately, students hope to use their work to compel others to think more deeply about the food that we purchase, cook, and eat.

post_text: Last Friday, Lucy Cannon-Neel, a Nulhegan Abenaki Tribal Council member as well as a healer and educator, visited with students in kindergarten through fourth grade. She spent the day sharing her Abenaki heritage and teaching the children about Abenaki culture pre-European contact. Students learned about housing, clothing, cuisine, gardening transportation, hunting fire building, communication, lore, community, music, and language. At the end of the day, students performed the songs and dances learned for their classmates in an assembly for pre-K through fourth. What an amazing and powerful visitor and visit! (Thank you Linda Savoca for making all the arrangements!)

To help high school students prepare for their radio shows (see below), they visited WGDR (91.1 FM) last week to gain insight into radio production as well as develop an appreciation for music as a physical artifact. Students were seeking to understand how appreciating music as a vinyl album differs from appreciating music through streaming and how that, in turn, affects our society's relationship with music.

By way of background info, students studying American history through the lens of music, culture, and politics will soon be creating radio documentary shows that examine the question: In what ways does culture, time and place shape the music we create and how does that music, in turn, shape culture, time and place?

During library classes in January and February, the third and fourth grade created a banner to represent Dr. King's dream for America after reading Martin's Big Words, by Doreen Rappaport, Be a King, by Carole Boston Weatherford and Malala's Magic Pencil by Malala Yousafzai. We encourage you to see the banner, which is now being shared with the entire town at the Cabot Public Library.

Artist Statement, Cabot School Third and Fourth Grades

"...we drew symbols for the words that represent his (Dr. King's) dreams and our dreams. Our banner shows symbols for magic, pride, belief, love, equality, friendship, peace, and many more hopes for our world. When we look at it, it will help us try to live the dream in our own way with everyone we meet."

Birds, birds and more birds were the topic of Siskin today. Students were taught how to read bird identification books while seeking out the special bird of Vermont ornithologist, Rosalind Renfrew, the bobolink.

The bobolink, winters in Argentina, and is clearly not in Vermont at the moment, but students did go out to see what birds they could find.

First and second graders found chickadees and their "dee" "dee" "dee's". Now they are waiting for the first signs of spring and the little bird's "cheesburger" "cheesburger" "cheesburger"!

What an inspiring day! Students from fifth grade through high school had the opportunity to meet with two women, Penny Patch and Cabot's own Lynn Rockwell, both of whom where a part of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC).

Penny Patch was the first white woman to take part in field work with the SNCC during the early '60s. Lynn Rockwell, who went to Alabama in the late 1960's, gathered survey answers that helped win a lawsuit against food and housing discrimination. Both women tell stories of conviction and courage with much that can be applied to the work still needed today.

This event was held in connection with the book, March by John Lewis the Vermont Reads Book of 2019 (Vermont Humanities Council). The middle schoolers have been reading March, but anyone can pick up a copy of the book at the school library or the Cabot Library and join the book discussion on Tuesday, February 12th. Dinner is at 6:30 and the discussion at 7:00 p.m. at the Cabot Library.

Please remember that physicals have to be up-to-date every two years. If your physical is about to expire or will expire during basketball season, please make an appointment for a physical. Physicals every two years are required in order to participate in athletics.
